title: skyes-limit-sabhal-mor-ostaig---unique-gaelic-only-college-set-stunning-island-location
story: Situated in the stunningly beautul peninsula of Sleat in the south end of the island, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is a unique Gaelic-only environment and the only college of its kind offering further and higher education through the medium of the language.The college offers a range of provision from beginnersrsquo courses to a PhD, with the flexibility of studying part-time or full-time, on campus or via distance learning. At a crucial time in the survival of the language, graduates have helped create a Gaelic speaking workforce that now holds key posts across a wide range of sectors in Scotland.Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is one of the key partners in fulfilling the governmentrsquos objectives in the National Gaelic Plan, which aims to increase the number of people speaking the language and accelerate the growth of Gaelic.Many people are keen to learn more about the language because of its rich culture and the college provides a wide range of short courses in Gaelic language, song and traditional music. Ceilidhs, workshops, conversation circles and music sessions all create an encouraging atmosphere that bring together students from  countries across five continents.As a modern, innovative college, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig has excellent learning resources on campus including an exceptional library collection, residential student accommodation, broadcast and recording facilities and a Gaelic medium childcare facility on site. It also has a growing international reputation for academic research.The college was founded on the principle of being part of the local and wider community and its activities are greatly enhanced by co-operative links, being home to a number of signicant national creative and cultural projects such as Tobar an Dualchais, Ainmean Agraveite na h-Alba and Cagravenan Graphics Studio. It plays a leading role in the promotion of the Gaelic arts and culture and also offers an international exchange programme with universities in Canada and Ireland.The collegersquos graduates include Seumas Greumach , Chief Executive of An Comunn Gaidhealach, which runs the Royal National Mod, who studied the Cugraversa Comais in  and then ed for another year to study Cagravenan is Cultar na Gagraveidhlig. He went to Sabhal Mograver to improve his language skills and says he would not hold his present job had he not become a fluent speaker.ldquoI was fully immersed in the language at Sabhal Mograver Ostaig, which is essential to become fluent in any language. he says. ldquoYou could hear Gaelic being spoken every day, in every situation and that helped me no end in improving my own Gaelic. I gained a great deal of confidence in terms of Gaelic grammar, spelling and writing, all of which has been invaluable in my working le.BBC weather presenter, Joy Dunlop, is another graduate of the college who says the fluency in Gaelic she developed at the college has given her many opportunities that she otherwise would not have had.She studied Gaelic as a second language when she was a pupil at Oban High School then decided to do her sixth year at the college. She initially planned to stay for just one year to do the Cugraversa Comais but loved it so much she stayed for four, graduating with a BAin Cagravenan agus Cultar na Gagraveidhlig .ldquoAttending Sabhal Mograver was a revelation for me, she says. ldquoThe education I received was unparalleled.ldquoThe personal support and guidance I received from all the staff was of the highest level and I always felt that our teachers were genuinely invested in both the language itself and our progress.ldquoBeing immersed in the language is definitely the best way to learn, dficult as it could be at times, and having the opportunity to speak Gaelic in both the classes and the community was a real help to me.ldquoSimply,you genuinely want to learn Gaelic, there is no better place to do so than Sabhal Mograver Ostaig. Tha i math agus tha i math dhut!

title: Rosemary Goring  39 s Country Life  the heated question of     heat
story: Here in the heart of the Borders, I look back on that flat with nostalgia. Aside from the occasional draught which we could dodge by retreating to the back room, it was wonderfully toasty. This was in large part thanks to generous neighbours above and below whose central heating kept us permanently cocooned.In the country, as I quickly learned, in winter there are two main subjects of conversation: weather and warmth, but the greater of these is warmth. Hoolet, like many villages around here, has no gas supply, so central heating runs either by electricity or oil. The topic of electricity bills leads to much sucking in of breath, although there was one couple whose house somehow escaped the notice of the electricity board.Only when they sold up and the new owners found they werenrsquot being charged did it become clear why there had always been such a blazing array of Christmas lights in this particular garden. Rumour has it that, years earlier, a woman in this area greased a palm and had her meter erted to a lamp-post. It took a while before the extraordinarily high reading was finally noticed and an investigation began. Soon she was tracked down, along with her cannabis plants.The day is approaching when wersquoll all have to switch to renewables, but in the meantime our radiators drink oil. Every few days I check the gauge on the tank in the garden, half-closing my eyes as I pull out the pin and watch it drop one inch, then two. Since it can take over a week between ordering and getting a refill, you have to estimate how long it will last. If nothing , becoming aware of every drop of oil you use does mean that, while itrsquos the least environmentally friendly of fuels, it is never squandered. One friend is so thrty her grandchildren have renamed her house The Baltic.Long before, and after, they became fashionable, everyone around here wears a gilet. People only come to their doors in a tee-shirttheyrsquove been interrupted in the process of layering. I was watching a western the other night and saw a tobacco-spitting rancher on his porch, rle under his stained armpit. What caught my attention was his long-johns, the sort that reach from ankle to chin to wrist, with buttons down the front. Theyrsquore exactly what I need.Other than the relief of seeing the orange lights of the oil tanker arriving in the pitch black of a winterrsquos morning, there is nothing interesting about oil. Our other source of heat, however, is wood-burning stoves, and on this subject I could win Mastermind. We have two, which possibly saved my husbandrsquos le. When the Beast From the East descended on Hoolet, he was left with a gaping hole in the kitchen wall where the boiler had been taken out moments before the blizzard started. The heating engineers fled to get over Soutra Hill before they were snowed in, and his ordeal began: two log fires and two hot water bottles to get him through five days until the roads reopened. When he went into the kitchen to cook dinner, he had to wear hat and gloves as well as his puffa jacket.There is nothing more comforting in the cold than a roaring fire. In rural parts this is not a lestyle choice but an absolute necessity. Of an evening we get through about five logs, which is enough to keep a large room really cosy. When we started out, we were so ignorant wersquod never even heard the phrase ldquokiln dried and ndash Irsquom going beetroot just thinking about it ndash we bought logs in bags from BQ. Now, having found a good supplier, and with our own woodstore, the first thing we notice as we drive around the area is other peoplersquos woodpiles.Some are works of art, high as a gable end and stacked so expertly theyrsquore as solid as drystane dykes. A few keep them in a ramshackle heap, out in the open, where they soak up the rain. Quite apart from the level of emissions wet wood produces, which is why itrsquos high on the governmentrsquos hit-list, it is far less efficient, generating less warmth and more smoke. Butyoursquore patient, green wood dries out ndash Irsquove heard you should wait two years for anything yoursquove cut down yourself. My father would have scoffed at that, as hersquod bring the car to a sudden halt, nip out and drag a huge storm-tossed branch into the boot ndash ldquotidying up the countryside as he put it. Back home, he stoked the flames so high we had to push the furniture back against the walls and open the living room door.The other day we had a delivery of ash, dumped in front of the house in a crate big enough to hold a wild boar. As the lumberjack was in bed barking like a sea-lion, it fell to me to deal with it. I was well on my way when Lazarus rose from the duvet to check on the proceedings and pointed out that I was laying them sideways rather than end-on. As the sun disappeared and clouds gathered I started again. By this time a neighbour had spotted me, and helped me finish the job.The sense of satisfaction in having it all safely stored, shortly before snowfall, was incalculable. Thatrsquos the thing about wood. The connection between you and the trees yoursquore burning creates a new respect and understanding. For a start, freshly chopped logs give off a delicious scent. And each one is dferent ndash whorled, fissured, misshapen, or neatly wedged like a giant slice of cake. If you chose to count the rings yoursquod see how many years had gone into making a blaze that lasts only a few hours.

title: can-anyone-see-happy-ending-ferry-tales
story: We cannot know what effects will linger from the experience of the past few months and those to come. It could be that the disruption caused by the coronavirus will turn out to be a relative blip and le willto normal, including regular travel abroad. Soon enough, the crowds could be back.It is not guaranteed, though. Travel, even at the best of times, is becoming more trouble than it is worth. Holidays abroad are increasingly spent recovering from the trip there and steeling oneself for the journey back. Hell is the modern airport.Given this, and increased awareness of climate change, more people will want to holiday close to home. Those who come from further afield will expect as eco-friendly a holiday as possible once they get here.Scotland is ideally placed to do well out of these changes. Or it would bewe had a transport system that was not a national embarrassment.The latest snafu is the cancellation of sailings between Brodick and Ardrossan. This is the busiest route in the CalMac network, serving , passengers. It is a flagship service in every sense, essential to Arran residents, businesses, and the wider tourist industry.There cannot be many Scots families who have not spent holidays on Arran. It is a fantastic island, the kind of place most countries would love to have a ferry ride away. The tourist board punts it as ldquoScotland in miniature but a better tag might be ldquoLike Vancouver Island, but closer.: Further ferry delays fearedNot only do Scots make good use of it, we recommend it, and indeed the rest of Scotland, wherever we go in the world. Yoursquoll have a great time, we tell people. To that we should add ldquoas long as you go at the right time.As far as travelling to Arran goes, now is not the best of times. It emerged this week that due to a fault with the mooring equipment ships can no longer berth safely in bad weather. According to CalMac the repairs could take up to six weeks, which runs right into the peak Easter holiday period.Why will it take so long  Because CalMac needs to source spare parts. If the parts were so essential one might imagine they would be held in stock, but that is to assume a level of efficiency that is proving beyond the service operators and their ultimate bosses, the Scottish Government.The latest problems take place against the backdrop of spiralling costs and y delays in the delivery of two new ferries. Vessels that should have cost pound million are now priced at more than double that, and they will not be in operation till  at least.Gavin Fulton, chair of Arran Ferry Action Group, has described the situation as ldquoa shambles. He told The Heraldrsquos reporter Martin Williams that patients on the island were having to spend up to five days on the mainland just to get to a hospital appointment and back.ldquoThings are going from bad to worse for us and there is no contingency plan, he added. ldquoThere is no word of chartering a boat, or to buy one abroad. It is a case of waiting  months for a new ferry and we have to put up with it.Mr Fulton is not alone in his despair. Another essential route, at the Rest and Be Thankful, is prone to closure due to landslips, forcing drivers on a -mile detour. It was announced recently that more millions are to be spent on repairs rather than a reroute of the A. Iain Jurgensen of the Argyll and The Isles Tourism Co-operative said it was ldquostaggering and irresponsible to keep spending public money on patching the problem rather than sorting it out once and for all.: Anger as services haltedIt is not just rural areas that are suffering from the lack of a joined up transport system in Scotland. Rail travel between two of the countryrsquos biggest cities is expensive, unreliable and overcrowded. Bus services across the country y wildly in price and efficiency. In Glasgow the subway does not operate on a Sunday evening. Too often the only way to ensure getting somewhere on time is to go by car, and even then good luck with the potholes.Of course there have been successes, chief among them the Queensferry Crossing. Leaving aside recent closures due to snow and ice the bridge was delivered with only a slight delay, again due to weather, and under budget, something of a miracle for large projects.Yet the Queensferry Crossing aside, Scotlandrsquos transport is too often in reverse or going nowhere fast.Part of the problem is that the subject has become politicised, alongside much  in Scottish le. Take the recent Queensferry Crossing closures. Instead of having a rational discussion about them, the row became another proxy war over Scottish independence. Criticising Scotlandrsquos transport, like questioning educational attainment or NHS waiting times, is seen as ldquotalking Scotland down.It would be funnyit was not so ridiculous. When you travel to another country you donrsquot give two toots of a horn who built what road and when, or who runs the ferry service.: Time to end monopoly of ownershipAll the traveller wants is a reliable service that will take them where they want to go at a reasonable cost both to themselves and the planet. That is what Scots desire as well, and it is not too much to ask.Transport is such an obvious building block for any successful country it should be above political bickering. Even given the problems of geography, it should not be beyond our ability to build a national transport infrastructure that works for all the people most of the time.Since nothing broadens the mind on transport like using the system, herersquos a suggestion. If more of our MPs and MSPs were to venture outside the Central Belt they could see the problems for themselves. Perhaps, once this latest spell of disruption is over, some of them could try commuting from Arran for a spell, or venture beyond the Rest and Be Thankful.Donrsquot forget to send us a postcardand when you arrive.

title: BUDGET SKETCH  Chancellor finds forest of magic money trees  Watch out  Boris
story: Mr Sunak, when seen on his own, looks a regular sized Chancellor. But put him beside someone of average height and build and he appears tiny. Like Stuart Little tiny. You see it when he walks up Downing Street beside another Minister, orhe is being interviewed one to one and the director cuts to a wide shot. On Sky News at the weekend he made the normally petite presenter Sophy Ridge look like the  foot woman, about to attack.Delivering his first Budget yesterday he seemed perfectly at ease. He looked taller, too. Perhaps he had been given a box to stand on, or maybe that is the sort of confidence a bespoke suit gives a chap.Mr Sunak has not been in the job long, having come to the position after the previous incumbent jumped ship in protest at Number rsquos proposed takeover of the Treasury. Dominic Cummings, the PMrsquos chief aide, was all for installing Larry the cat as Chancellor. In the end, Mr Sunak got the job.Among his tasks yesterday was to show that he was a man, not a mouser, and his own man at that. Before he could get to the juicy part of the Budget, handing out the ribbon-wrapped goodies to all his new pals on the Tory backbenches, he addressed the coronavirus crisis.The Commons heard that one fth of the working age population might need to take time off work . That is a lot of people sitting at home watching Phil and Holly on This Morning.Now, you may have been under the impression these last ten years that the UKrsquos finances amounted to whatever spare change could be found down the back of the sofa in  Downing Street. Money was tight, and it was vital to balance the books, so austerity ruled, spending was slashed, and those on benefits had to be squeezed till their pips squeaked. No one wanted to do this, you understand, but as a former PM said, there was no such thing as a magic money tree.Well, it turns out Mr Sunak has discovered a forest of magic money trees. He shook this one, then that one, showering cash left, right and centre. Speaking of left and right, Mr Sunak decided he was going to merge all three positions into one and make Labour redundant. It was the Conservatives, he said, who were ldquothe real workersrsquo party and ldquothe party of public services. Just to further annoy comrade Corbyn he boasted, Blair-like, of delivering ldquoa peoplersquos Budget.The closest the Chancellor came to a half way decent gag was when he abolished VAT on digital books, including ldquoworks of fantasy like John McDonnellrsquos Economics for the Many. Sitting opposite, the man who would have been Chancellor had Labour miraculously won the election, laughed and felt in his pocket ashe was going to reprise his Maorsquos Little Red Book joke of five years ago. A rubbish joke then, age had not improved it.The Chancellorrsquos main rf, one that he ed to again and again, was that the Conservatives were ldquogetting it done. It was the bossrsquos line about Brexit, or was it Cummings who had coined it  Either way, the Chancellor said it so often and with such relish it was ashe had adopted it for his own. Little man, big ambition. Watch out, Boris.

title: brian-beacom-dating-modern-world
story: I looked up and tried to form a bold smile as I lied through my capped teeth. ldquoSo many that my doormat took such a battering Irsquom off to BQ this afternoon to buy a new one.I was entirely unconvincing. The reality consumed both of us. Irsquom single. Uncoupled now for some time, Irsquom almost the age of a Beatles song ndash and I donrsquot feel fine at all.When you reach a certain age you simply canrsquot hang out in bars for fear of being seen as a saddo. The past is another country in which every Friday night was fun night, getting wrecked on white wine spritzers and meeting women themselves a little worse for wear.Some  years on, meeting potential partners is far more problematic. And you canrsquot assume friends will endorse you to single women of their knowing being unmarried at a certain age means women see you as a hopeless case.So what to do  Give up  Get an allotment  Yes, I have to take matters into my own hands. As John Donne almost said, ldquoNo man is an island. And he needs someone to go to the Grosvenor with on a Saturday night with.But itrsquos not easy. As well as the lack of opportunity to meet people, you have to battle against your own torpidity. After a while youget used to your own routine.Then therersquos the fussiness you develop over the years. I once went on a blind date and discovered the meeting to be utterly pointless the moment I noted the femalersquos shoesndash worn for a lunchtime coffee. Therersquos another issue with being single and ageing. The passing years offer experience, a knowing of what you need in a partner, and this knowledge can be inhibiting. Realising you want someone who is intelligent, challenging and fun ndash but also someone who is serious, thoughtful and kind is a heavy boulder to shove. Realising blondes certainly assert themselves on the eye , and that yoursquore a sucker for high cheekbones and a cheeky glint is daunting.Yes, Irsquom asking a lot. And to add to that list I just donrsquot feel comfortable with women bigger than me. So, prospective partners have to be able to limbo under a size  bar.There are notes of optimism, however, to bring to this rather cynical partner quest. Having mutually split with my long-term partner , Irsquove since learned where I truly went wrong:yoursquore going to be with someone for a very long time you should assume they would love to be married. Eventhey never offer the slightest indication of such.Can I commit  Irsquod like to think so. So where to begin with this search to find a we Itrsquos been claimed that more than  per cent of marriages begin online these days, according to figures supplied by the Statistic Brain Research Institute. Thatrsquos good, isnrsquot it Well, Irsquom not so sure. It all seems like HMDI cable connection love. I prefer some form of personal interest to predicate the meeting. I quite liked the high school ldquoMy pal fancies your pal arranged dating, and I thought the premise of the early lonelyhearts agencies to be absolutely sound.My education into this world began in the Kelburne Cinema in  when I watched Carry On Loving. I liked this world. All you had to do was wander into the Wedded Bliss dating agency, the little high street love shop run by Sid Blissand thebig-hearted Sophie Plummett , who would flick through a box of cards and pick out someone whorsquos exactly your type.I recall at  wonderingSophie could pick out someone for me.Fty years on, Irsquom wondering exactly the same thing, except that the personal finger of selection has gone and electronic algorithms, not Sophie, will be used to make the selection. No, Irsquom not keen on this online business at all. Yes, I know seven million in the UK alone are registered. But how can a list of preferences predict chemistry I tell myself to shut up. And havenrsquot the likes of Sharon Stone, Melanie Sykes and Ulrika Jonsson gone online to find a special friend  If nothing , this suggests there are some interesting women out there.Time to start. The first place has to be Tinder, doesnrsquot it  For one thing, the phone download is free. All you have to do is swipe in the direction of the female of your choice, hope that yoursquore her choice and arrange a meet. And before you can say ldquoCongratulations, yoursquore taking her up the aisle.Or are you  For me, the reality of Tinder turns out to be something rather dferent. I wonder, ldquoDo I look as old as some of the women Irsquom swiping away  What a frightening thought.What I also find hard to comprehend is why someone would post pics of themselves with a Bambi nose superimposed, or little devil horns, or cartoon whiskers. Christ, I donrsquot want to go out with a Hanna-Barbera cartoon.What you also learn is that some of the women are eastern European and, rather surprisingly, seem keen to have a much older, rather well-off boyfriend. Perhaps I should be wary.What I do like about Tinder, however, is that people are fairly obvious as to their requirement. I like the women who say, ldquoNo hook-ups, which means they donrsquot want a one-night stand.Yet a Psychology Today profile of Tinder suggests Irsquom more likely to meet a short-termist on Tinder. ldquoSome of those iniduals motivated by such social pressure and instant gratication are also more impulsive, less likely to be faithful and committed, and more interested in having sex for casual reasons, claimed the writer.Irsquove also discovered another possible Tinder problem. One PR company recently created male Tinder profiles, ensuring the name, picture and age remained unchanged, but changed the job title.Claiming to be a builder, they said, nearly doubles your chances of a being Liked. Now, I can hammer home a decent metaphor, mix up a decent simile but I canrsquot treat a damp patchfor the le of me.What I canrsquot nail is a Tinder match. At the last count, Irsquod counted up -odd likes and there are females Irsquove liked the look profile of. But the problem is we donrsquot like each other. It makes me wonder how an app which can have  pages about me on my filendash and million users ndash canrsquot match me up. Surely Sophie Plummett would have pulled someone out of the hat Itrsquos time to look online again. And be optimistic  A survey carried out by dating site Badoo found that people in Glasgow had the best chance in Scotland of landing their Saturday night date. But thatrsquos not love. Thatrsquos a lumber.It seems the problem with internet dating is it represents the paradox of choice. Danish philosopher Soren Kierkegaard once wrote of ldquothe dizziness of freedom. He could have been thinking about the huge volume of internet dating options out there, the anxiety that so much online choice can create. He could have been thinking that, while choice has soared, personal connection has dissolved.Psychologist Michael Rosenfield has underlined this problem. He suggests that finding an online partner is all about learning, narrowing down your criteria,just in case you seek ldquoa same-sex partner, or a partner who is a vegetarian mountain-climbing Catholic.Well, I donrsquot, as it happens. But isnrsquot this all a bit soulless  Does tossing more algorithms at a robot really increase our chances  Or at the end of the day, do we simply connect or not  How can we work out what we want in a partner ndash even when we can never be exactly sure until we meet that person.And letrsquos go back to Glasgow. Online dating company Eharmony says itrsquos ldquothe most single city in Scotland. However, the reasons are not encouraging. ldquo per cent of Glaswegians have given up on finding love completely,  per cent feel overwhelmed by the modern dating landscape and  per cent think theyrsquoll be single forever.Wow. Thatrsquos depressing stuff. The company cites lack of confidence and low self-esteem as playing a major factor. Well, that doesnrsquot apply personally but I have to admit Irsquom edging towards ldquothe  per cent who worry their age is having a negative effect on their search for love.The survey goes on to cite negative past relationships as a factor, and meeting the wrong people on bad dates. ldquoIn fact, a quarter of Glaswegian singles have not had a relationship in over  years.Oh, dear. The allotment beckons. Or having to sign up for a singles holiday in Machu Picchu where Irsquoll meet lots of sturdy women in combat pants and open-toed sandals.I try another internet dating service. Itrsquos called Ourtime and within a couple of hours of filling in the forms I have  likes. I donrsquot knowthatrsquos good or bad. I do know it will cost pound. a month to find out who fancies me. Then therersquos Elite. Which isnrsquot very. Itrsquos claimed to be the dating agency for professionals. I try that one too, but what is a professional  Elite seems to think itrsquos hairdressers or care workers.The website also seems to disregard geography. I declared I wanted to meet someone within a -mile radius and up pops Sandra from Craigavon and Maisie from Nottingham I know. If I were really that keen on finding love Irsquod open my arms to Maisies. I need to widen my outlook. I need to be positive and, like the other singletons, remind myself I live in a city thatrsquos been spiritually blessed by a love saint. St Valentinersquos remains are to be found in St Francisrsquos Church in the Gorbals. And didnrsquot Glasgow proclaim itself to be the City of Love in . That has to help What  can I try  My friend Liam suggests I try Thursday nightsat Waitrose and try to connect over a nice piece of haddock. But then he suggests I follow St Val into church. ldquoGo to mass to meet women, he enthuses. ldquoThere are loads of singles. Andtheyrsquove got kids, all you do is wait until they send the weans up for the Eucharist before making your move.I laugh because Irsquom thinking itrsquos not the craziest idea hersquos ever had. But on the other hand therersquos a real chance I could be hit by a bolt of lightningI recalibrate St Margaretrsquos Chapel as a pick-up place.What of the standard places to meet people these days  Salsa clubs  Yoga  Theyrsquore such a clicheacute but then you have to be in it to win it. Thatrsquos the feeling of Yvonne Carvel, who, along with Diane Goudie, runs the Raeburn Supper Club, which offers a meeting place ndash dinner or events ndash for  to -year-olds.ldquoInternet dating is popular but wersquove been going for  years now and we realised it isnrsquot for everybody. Wersquove learned of lots of less than pleasant experiences.Carvel points out chemistry can only be discovered with a personal meet. ldquoIf you come to a supper club you are met by one of us and itrsquos so much easier to break the ice. And those who register get the chance to meet lots of new friends, with the possibility this may lead to something .She adds, smiling: ldquoAnd it has, on many occasions.What I have learned is that effort is required,chances of meeting someone special are to be realised. Yes, Irsquoll have to advertise myself because standard social structures for meeting people donrsquot really apply as you move into your fties and sixties. Irsquoll have to submit to all-day-long evaluation before complete, often disinterested, sometimes mocking strangers who may find themselves just as dismissive as me because theyrsquore feeling just as anxious.I have to accept that single people need to shop themselves around. In an online blurb can I convince anyone Irsquom sexy, funny, intelligent, honest and decent ndash and the pics are recent.I have to push aside the statistic that claims that . per cent of women agree that money plays a part in how attractive they find a partner.And even though most online relationships fail, one in three begins online. Hang on, herersquos another statistic to end on. Glasgow has been dubbed the British capital of female singletons, with the highest number of single women in the UK, the city having , more single women than men.Surely these are odds I can work with But I canrsquot help thinking itrsquos a Sophie Plummett I need rather than an algorithm.

title: ron-mackenna-not-taste---no-denying-joint-fans
story: Wersquore talking at this table about the enormous To Let sign hanging right outside Bread Meats Bread tonight. And what it means. ldquoNot closing, just moving, says the fresh-faced and chirpy young waiter when asked.When and where, hersquos not sure, maybe six months, probably somewhere bigger. Possibly not the greatest thing for a business to have outside, though, and when I see it tonight en route to find outitrsquos true that Glasgowrsquos Bread Meats Bread now allegedly makes one of the best  burgers in the world, crikey, I almost do a cartoon u-turn.To head instead to one of those new fish taco places popping out everywhere. But itrsquos Wednesday, itrsquos pm and through the enormous square windows I can see a warm glow, a lot of people, a rude healthiness: frankly itrsquos pretty busy.Theyrsquoll sing songs one day about the great burger revolution of, say, eight years ago, of Americarsquos Man v Food, of hipsters and authentic ingredients and the earnest race to make a better burger and of how little Bread Meats Bread here fought off the competition to become not justthe last man standing, but part of a mini Scottish chain with a global reputation. Okay, they probably wonrsquot.But students will surely make documentaries ndash they already have. Although hands up, confession time: I didnrsquot really rate the burgers here when I came back in the day, but whether itrsquos Betamax v VHS, Windows v Apple or simply location, location, location therersquos no denying this place has fans.Mainly but not exclusively males tonight all ages, whisky-loving middle-agers, I see a guy over there chowing down while wearing an actual orange-faced Doxa Submariner watch, a lone Japanese customer at a bench, ayoung couple gazing at each other oblivious to the swooping and swiping at the open grill area above and behind. True story: Irsquoll walk out onto slushy St Vincent Street later just as a clutch of English accents go rushing by and a man will turn and without stopping look up and shout: ldquoHey, great name. But are they great burgers At first I sit at one of those goldfish bowl bench tables thatrsquos at the corner of St Vincent Street and Renfield Street and fight against BTrsquos relentlessly aggressive, greedy, overpriced internet pop-up nonsense from taking over my laptoprsquos wi-fi, but then a back-wall two-seater becomes available and I move to where I can see inside and not just out.The menursquos been through a few hands by the time I get it, but theyrsquove been round the block in here, and itrsquos changed from what I remember too. More buttermilk fried chicken burgers, a plant-based burger from Moving Mountains with, er, genuine bleeding patties, hot dogs too.: Joanna Blythman: It seems to march to its own tune, successfully, for the most part.Their signature burger comes with nduja, pulled pork, BBQ sauce and Sriracha, which gets full marks for covering all the bases. Irsquom no fan of the pile-it-high,bury-the-taste school of burgers so the pound. Cheeseburger is ordered, the small poutineand ndash simply because Irsquom curious ndash a Kimcheese Toastie at pound..The toastiersquos big, toasted properly, sticky, melting and served with a pile of green pickles. The Canadian-style poutine is all bland white curds looking like caullower, a ladle of brown gravy, a few golden chips sticking up like the masts of foundered chips.The burger itself comes in a wrinkled bun, buttered Irsquod say, completely and properly toasted, melting cheese running down what looks like properly charred meat. Theyrsquove got presentation down to almost an art form.Taste  Kimchi toastie  Ooyah: overwhelmed by the taste of that pungent cabbage, and wet at the bottom. Poutine  Harmless and inoffensive.And that burger  The right texture to the bun, clearly carefully prepared, but I find the meat dense, tasting of nothing much and a bit gristly in parts.Bread Meats Bread St Vincent StreetGlasgowTel   Hours am-pm. Seven days.Menu: Itrsquos on an internet list of the worldrsquos top  burgers, plus vegan bleeders, poutines, buttermilk chicken as expected.  Service: No complaints from me, freshly cheery, swt and the food reached the table in a reasonable time.  Atmosphere: Woody, hipstery, open-kitchen vibe, itrsquos part of a mini chain but still pulls off a welcoming feel.  Price: Slap, bang in primo territory in Glasgowrsquos city centre, those rates ainrsquot gonna be cheap but I thought the pricing was reasonable in the circumstances.  Food: Is it fast food with a bit of a hand-made spin  If so itrsquos all of that. Is it one of the worldrsquos best burgers  If so, I had nothing that special to eat and the burger itself wasnrsquot for me.  Total:

title: finance-secretary-denies-free-bus-travel-plan-cynical-sham
story: The SNP Finance Secretary said she was completely serious about the plan, which was included in a last-minute deal with the Greens on the   budget last month.And she rubbished claims by the Scottish Tories that the scheme was a sham to get the Greens on board.As part of Ms Forbesrsquos first budget, the fourth between the Greens and SNP since , she gave an ldquoin principle commitment to implement the concessionary travel scheme, backed by poundm.However there were caveats.The plan is subject to due diligence and the ldquoaim is to have this done to allow it to start in January, not a guarantee.The Tories have seized on the language to claim the SNP will cynically jettison the pledge.But Ms Forbes, who became Finance Secretary last month after the exit of Derek Mackay in disgrace, told the PA news agency: ldquoWe wouldnrsquot have committed to initial investmentwe didnrsquot believe that it was a good policy.ldquoWersquove already identied several streams of work around how it operates, consulting particularly young people around what they want to see and also inevitably around the due diligence and the legalities, which we have to do.She added: ldquoIn the budget statement, I gave a commitment to begin that work but any new policy has to be subject to due diligence.However she refused to give a timetable for the confirmation of the scheme going ahead - saying only she hoped the preparatory work would continue ldquoat pace.She added: ldquoWersquore committed to trying to make this work.Tory MSP Murdo Fraser said: ldquoThe SNP hasnrsquot committed to introducing free bus travel for under s, they have only committed to investigating it.ldquoThe Scottish Green Party appears to be the only group of people still fooled by this ploy.ldquoThe question is when will Kate Forbes drop the pretence and finally admit that itrsquos not going to happen.Green co-leader Patrick Harvie said: ldquoWe know this policy will work and can be achieved on the timescale set out in our agreement.ldquoIt will be a truly transformational move, saving struggling families money, widening opportunities for people starting out in le and encouraging people to leave their cars at home.

title: suspicious-budget-spending-pledges-not-seem
story: Westminster CorrespondentFINANCE experts have warned that the Chancellorrsquos Budget spending spree promises are ldquonowhere near as generous as they appear.The Institute for Fiscal Studiessaid that Rishi Sunakrsquos commitment to splash the cash on Wednesday is not as it seems, when EU funding and previously agreed spending is taken into account.The financial watchdogs warned that there would be ldquolittle left for departments which had not already had funding increases decided before the budget.Paul Johnson, director of the IFS gave a post-budget briefing yesterday, where he said: ldquoThe current spending plans are nothing like as generous as they appear.ldquoAverage annual increases of .% sound substantial take account of the need to replace EU funding and factor in planned increases for health, schools, defence and overseas aid and there is relatively little here for other departments.ldquoIf this spending envelope is stuck to, there are plenty of public services which will not be enjoying much in the way of spending increases over the next few years.Along with pessimism about Sunakrsquos pledges, Johnson added that tax increases could be on the cards in future as the Chancellorrsquos plans look ldquosuspiciously front-loaded.He explained: ldquoSpending increases pencilled in for the next two years are much bigger than what follows. This could suggest top ups in later budgets and hence a need for more tax or more borrowing.On the economic forecasts, he said: ldquoProjected growth rates averaging barely over .% a year for the next five years are feeble, frankly.ldquoAnd they are indicative of an economy that is not in a robust position to deal with shocks like the coronavirus.Mr Johnson branded the Budget an ldquoodd affair.He said it was ldquoreally two budgets rolled into one, adding: ldquoThere was the normal Budget setting out medium term tax and spending plans.ldquoAnd then there was the emergency Budget aimed at dealing with immediate potential consequences of the coronavirus.ldquoThe latter made the former a rather odd affair.Another of the watchdogrsquos conclusions is that by , spending per person for most public services will be ldquowell below what it was in , when David Cameron took office and former a coalition government with the Liberal Democrats and at a similar level to what it was during austerity times.Their conclusion states: ldquoOutside of health, spending per person will still be % lower, and around % lower once you account for the spending that is simply replacing EU funding.Ben Zaranko, research economist at the IFS said: ldquoTaking the Government figures at face value, day-to-day spending on public services is set to increase now and be almost % higher by  than it was in . If we put that into per-person terms, to account for the growth of the population, it is set to be almost exactly the same in   as it was in  , so we will be back where we were before the era of austerity.ldquoIf we strip out health, real terms spending will be % lower in  than it was  years previously.Meanwhile Labourrsquos shadow chancellor John McDonnell said the budget did not go far enough to help those in poverty or who are vulnerable, criticising the lack of investment for social care.Speaking yesterday in the House of Commons, McDonnell said it wasunclear what additional support is being provided and added: ldquoThe majority of people who do receive social care are older, disabled or vulnerable people. We have an pound billion funding gap in social care budgets, as the result of ten years of austerity. Providers and local authorities are already stretched to near breaking point. We need to know how much additional support is being provided.Alison Thewliss, the SNPrsquos shadow chancellor, said it was a ldquodisgrace that the Scottish Governmentrsquos finance minster Kate Forbes had to carry out her budget ldquoblindfolded and added:It is wholly unacceptable that Scottish local authorities, which had a legal deadline of yesterday to set their budgets and council tax, had to do so without knowing precisely how much they would have to spend.ldquoNow we find that Scotlandrsquos budget next year will be lower in real terms than when the Tories first came to power.ldquoThese proposals do nothing to redress the cumulative cuts or the short-changing of city and region deals.

title: un-climate-summit-change-way-glaswegians-eat-forever
story: However, the arrival of world leaders and environmental campaigners to the United Nationrsquos conference COP could actually end up altering the way Glaswegians eat.The gathering, which is the largest summit ever held in the UK, will see world leaders along with , environmental campaigners and scientists descend on the city, many with high expectations of finding ethically sourced and sustainable food to keep them going through the -day event.As a result, demand is expected to soar in the city for hyper-local, high-welfare and ethical food which meets the delegatesrsquo vision for less damaging manner of food production.At the same time, the climate change conference will coincide with the launch of a major city-wide food plan, designed to help Glasgow become carbon neutral by .The timing of the unveiling of Glasgowrsquos City Food Plan, the first plan of its kind in Scotland ndash just as delegates descend for COP ndash has raised expectations that it will include highly ambitious ideas for feeding the city in the future.That could include visionary concepts, such as the creation of allotments on former municipal golf courses, rooftops, cemeteries, hospitals, schools and the grounds of historic buildings.Those have all been mooted in Glasgow Food Growing Strategyrsquos draft paper which looks at how the city can produce a more erse range of produce to meet diet trends and climate pressure.It is set to end its public consultation next month, just as Glasgowrsquos City Food Plan enters its own consultation period and coinciding with preparations for COP in November.Between April and June citizens, communities, businesses and organisations in Glasgow, including those who work in the food industry, will be invited to give their views on the draft City Food Plan based on their knowledge of what works and what more is needed to improve the cityrsquos food system.Then, from June until August the Plan will be reviewed according to comments received before being formally launched between September and November, when COP begins.The Planrsquos ambitions chime with the ethos of the climate activists and campaigners from around the globe who are expected to anchor themselves on the River Clyde at the Scottish Event Campus in coracles, canoes and yachts in anticipation for the arrival of young climate activist Greta Thunberg.Food production is a key focus for environmental campaigners: it contributes - per cent of the carbon emissions that drive climate change though production, processing, storage, transportation and disposal.However, the Glasgow delegates will find a number of grassroots food initiatives are already under way.They include three market gardens which supply local restaurants and deliver hundreds of organic veg boxes each week, community orchards and social enterprise supermarket, Locavore, which is set to expand into the city centre, helping more money spent there to stay in the local economy.There are also currently  community gardens and growing spaces root across the city along with  allotment sites while start-up funding is supporting the local food production.The city is also recognised for its high number of vegan restaurants.But while Glasgowrsquos restaurants are celebrated there remains diet and poverty-related food problems, a lack of growing space, and a disjointed approach to delivering more ethically-sourced and environmentally-friendly food which has led to well-meaning initiatives and schemes being implemented separately.The City Food Plan is expected to pull all the threads together ndash including the results of the Glasgowrsquos Food Growing Strategy consultation ndash to create a visionary approach to tackling the cityrsquos relationship with food for the first time.ldquoThere are lots of enthusiastic and innovative people and projects working on food across the city who would benefit from a more coordinated approach to the issues in our food system, said Abi Mordin of the Glasgow Community Food Network.ldquoWe want to involve as many of Glasgowrsquos citizens and businesses in shaping our City Food Plan and in making it happen. We are very excited about it and delighted that Glasgow is taking the initiative ahead of any other Scottish city.ldquoWe now have a proper chance to change Glasgowrsquos food culture for the better, and the imminent arrival of COP can only help give it more impetus.

title: issue-day-joe-biden-revival
story: Joe BidenhellipJust one month ago, he was being written off after a poor performance in the New Hampshire primary - the first in a series of nationwide party primary elections to determine the party nominees for the presidential elections later in the year. He finished fth and it seemed unlikely he would bounce back, but he has gone on to win a raft of primaries.To secure the nomination you requirehellip A candidate needs the backing of , delegates. After winning Michigan this week, Biden so far has  delegates, while Sanders has .Hersquos  He will turn  on November th,  days after the US election is due to be held. Trump will turn  in June and became president when he was , so is currently the oldest president in history. Biden,elected president, would become the oldest Commander in Chief.The White House is at least familiar The Pennsylvanian-born politician - first elected to the Senate in the s - was vice president to Barack Obama from  till . He previously bid for the nomination ahead of the  election, before withdrawing.Because He was accused of plagiarism after making a speech containing an almost identical section to a chunk of a speech given by Labour Party leader, Neil Kinnock, in , talking about his background and saying, ldquoWhy am I the first Kinnock in a thousand generations to be able to get to university  Biden said a few months later: ldquoWhy is it that Joe Biden is the first in his family ever to go to a university Sorrows In , his first we, Neilia, and one-year-old daughter were killed in a car accident. His two sons, Beau and Hunter, survived, but Beau died in  at the age of  from a rare form of brain cancer.Bromance Throughout Obamarsquos presidency, the pairrsquos chemistry was picked up on, often setting social media alight with images of them together becoming memes.And just as they prepared to leave office in , Obama surprised Biden by presenting him with the Presidential Medal of Freedom, saying he was "The best vice president America has ever had, adding: "This also gives the internet one last chance to talk about our bromance.Straight talker In a clash over gun control with a factory worker in Michigan earlier this week, Biden - furious at being accused of wanting to take Americans guns away - told the worker he was "full of ****" and to "not be such a horses ***.Trump His most recent Biden tweet said simply: ldquoI will protect your Social Security and Medicare, just as I have for the past  years. Sleepy Joe Biden will destroy both in very short order, and he wonrsquot even know hersquos doing it!MAUREEN SUGDEN

title: herald-diary-kane-able
story: WITH everyone advised to take extra care washing their hands, schoolchildren have been informed that their soap scrub-a-dubbing should last as long as it takes to sing "Happy Birthday" twice. title: letters-need-take-decisive-action-virus-right-now
story: While other countries stop travel, shut schools, universities, public spaces and lockdown to stop the spread, we seem transfixed by the inconvenience this will cause. China, Singapore and Taiwan have shown how determined intervention can radically reduce cases. The number of new cases in China is now below  from , a day in February. They combined quarantine with the rigorous tracing of contacts and infection sources. There were substantial rewards given to people presenting with symptoms and larger onescases were proved. Yet here we seem unable to plan decisive early intervention.Scotland should give a lead in this. Each day that is lost means more cases and ultimately more suffering and loss of le.Professor Greg Philo, Glasgow University.WONDERFUL. Instead of taking drastic action now to limit the spread of coronavirus as fast as possible, we will just make le a bit more dficult and spin out the process, so that we can stay in this limbo for longer before we deliver the full restrictions needed to beat the virus. Fine. Letrsquos consider the economy, donrsquot damage it too much yet, just a little bit, and letrsquos wait till the virus has had more time to spread, and we can add the killer blow later. Meantime, we will just leave people will just have to worry and suffer inconvenience for a bit longer, until the situation is really dire.Why on earth did we not impose full restrictions in the limited areas where the virus first appeared, and any subsequently affected areas, to try to contain it when there was less to contain  Would that not have shortened the likely overallof time needed to win the battle and to have reduced the hit on the economy as well L McGregor, Falkirk.WHEN the Clydebank Health Centre opened in  I was asked what I thought of it. I said I thought it was a bad move. Instead of being able to visit my GP locally I was now forced to travel about a mile and a half some residents of the town would face an even longer walk.Not a great distanceyou are young and fit, but a fair distanceyou are elderly, and or have mobility problems. You may probably be feeling ill, hence a visit to your GP becomes a chore.I also said it was a bad idea to have all the GPs in the one building. "What happensbubonic plague, or something similar breaks out  All your eggs are now in one basket." I was told not to be facetious.Is it time to have a rethink about local health centres and who staffs them George Smith, Clydebank.WILLIE Maclean suggests suspension of the National Lottery to reduce supermarket footfall and hence yielding health risk reduction.Perhaps Mr Maclean has not taken account of the numbers of customers already in supermarkets either for regular shopping or for the panic-buying of toilet rolls who buy their tickets as a matter of course.I know of no one who makes a special journey for this purpose.David Miller, Milngavie.Read more: People with coronavirus symptoms to stay at home for seven days

title: letters-standard-living-undoubtedly-plummet-scotland-leave-union
story: Quite why we should base current policy on figures from  to , as Mr Galloway prefers, is easy to see: he thinks they support a case for leaving the UK whereas, as we all know, post- figures do not. It is a surprise to see anyone mention oil when the global price is now around - per barrel. Scarcely the  per barrel on which the SNP based its  campaign ndash and Andrew Wilson, its growth guru has admitted that that was the case. Currently ndashI am allowed to use current data ndash it is costing more to extract North Sea oil than the oil brings in income to oil companies. This is similar to the position in - when oil brought in no revenue to the public purse. ImagineScotland had voted Yes in  and the price of oil had then collapsed  It does not bear thinking about.It is a fact, acknowledged by Ms Sturgeon and others in the SNP hierarchy, that Scotland has a deficit that is too large. We retain our current favourable standard of living because of the fiscal transfer from HM Treasury. People like Mr Hill may wriggle about that, but rather than "destroying any case for the Union", as he claims, it underscores the vital importance of Scotland remaining in the Union in which our prosperity has been generated. He may not mindhis standard of living plummets. I doubt I am alone in minding that very much.Jill Stephenson, Edinburgh EH.JILL Stephensonis wrong when she states that Scotland receives almost pound, per head of population subsidy over the UK average. In fact the figure is closer to pound,. What she did not say is there are good demographic reasons for this given the sparse population and the need to provide essential public services over a wide rural area. Another factor which muddies her comparison is the fact that Scottish Water is not privatisedand therefore contributes to the anomaly. What she also fails to mention is that Wales and London are similar to Scotland at pound, and pound, respectively above the UK average of pound,. Northern Ireland at pound, is pound, above the U.K. average. All of these figures for   can be checked via the House of Commons Library.Some people of a Unionist persuasion will do anything to talk Scotland down in an attempt to undermine the case for Scottish independence. Scotland is big enough, smart enough and rich enough to take our place in the family of nations as opposed to the debt-ridden UK which is about to plunge into even more debt over the next four or five years.Alec Oattes, Ayr.JILL Stephenson would like to know "what benefits devolved rule has brought to Scotland". How about the following Free bus travel for the elderly ndash offering freedom of movement for some hard-up friends and neighbours.The Gaelic Language Act,  ndash pointlessyou donrsquot value Gaelic, but a boon to grateful learners like me.Minimum pricing of alcohol. On its own, it wonrsquot solve our strong drink problem, but at least itrsquos a start.Proportional representation in national and local elections, which makes my vote count, while at UK level I still suffer the capricious curse of "first past the post".Ministers in a government elected by the people and not ndash as was the case in the old Scottish Office days ndash nominated by whatever party happened to win power in London.John Coutts, Stirling.ALEXANDER McKay constantly questions the Scottish Governments abilities . Proof of its competence lies in the , affordable homes and , homes for social rent built since , delivered by the Scottish Government. Eighteen more are currently under construction in Kilbarchan!Colin Campbell, Kilbarchan.

title: coronavirus-social-distancing-takes-toll-need-community-get-us
story: "Its not as bad as flu," he said, "It doesnt kill people the way normal flu does," while one of the guests tried to interject with a correction. The gent would not be corrected and demanded to know where the guest was sourcing his fake news from.He cited a completely reputable news source only to be told this was nonsense and not in line with what the president was saying.Visions of Donald Trumps utterly incompetent national address floated in front of my eyes, alongside mental screenshots of the presidents tweet that the media was not giving him enough praise for his handling of the outbreak.General approaches to the worsening news about coronavirus seem to fit into distinct camps: dismissive to the point of denial alarmed to the point of frantic and incoherent panic buying of toilet roll those with a keenness to start protective measures as soon as possible and those who only started to worry when they learned Tom Hanks was ill.Personally, Ive gone from extreme eye-rolling at the stockpilers to thinking it might be useful to ensure my mum has some tins and powered milk in, just in case.I have friends who are already keeping or planning to keep their children home from school. Others are cancelling plans and spending more time at home, other than essential work or grocery trips. Others still are cancelling holidays abroad.The one thing in common to these proactive approaches is that they arent making these changes to protect themselves - theyre doing it with their thoughts on their elderly relatives.And the one thing we all have in common is that we surely all know someone who is particularly vulnerable to severe illness should they catch the coronavirus. That,nothing , must be the uniting factor that pulls us through this crisis.Because, despite being told that this will be the worst health crisis in a generation, petty discord is still being created. Following yesterdays COBRA meeting, Nicola Sturgeon gave a public briefing about where we are and what the next steps will be.Commentators wound themselves up at the fact Ms Sturgeon went ahead before Boris Johnson had a chance to give his national briefing, these commentators sniping asshe was a prime ministerial understudy, rather than the leader of a country.This really isnt the time for constitutional squabbles. A well kent journalist called the First Ministers actions "a borderline coup detat". Things have certainly taken a turn for the mundane since the days of the Rum Rebellion.A so-far relaxed Boris Johnson put a fine point on it during yesterdays post-COBRA briefing. "I must level with the British public," the prime minister said, "Many more families are going to lose their loved ones before their time."This is, incidentally, from the same prime minister who was only in the last few days showing a cavalier attitude to handshakes, despite having a pregnant partner at home.In the coming days and weeks it is likely that people will be asked to work from home. Large events will be cancelled its possible that schools will be closed. There will be claim and counter claim, back and forth, about whether our respective governments are doing enough to stem the outbreak. There will be disputes about whether they are working effectively together.In a more minor way, social distancing will be expected - staying two metres or so away from other people, avoiding unnecessary trips out. There will be grumbling, at best, and lonely isolation, at worst.The crisis will show just how much we rely on unpaid care work to keep things ticking over. Grandparents, who fill so many of the childcare gaps, will have to step back from their duties for their own protection. The slack pulled by those of us who have caring responsibilities for older and elderly relatives will be stark.School closures, of course, have a much broader impact than exams being cancelled. Exams, while this is stressful for young people who are relying on results to steer choices that will shape their futures, can be rearranged.What of the pupils who take free school meals or attend breakfast clubs or holiday lunch clubs - for them education comes with a literal side serving, and one that is vital to making ends meet in straitened homes.There was concern expressed by a medical expert that cancelling sports matches will only serve to push people to gather in pubs to watch games.In a political climate where the focus is on the inidual, we will have to radically alter our thinking to focus on the collective good during this crisis.We will need to be willing to sacrice our pleasures - sports, the cinema, theatre and gigs. When stocking up on those extra tins, there must be a pause to consider whether we really need as many as were taking or are we leaving someone who is more vulnerable without.On Facebook groups have already sprung up encouraging those who are willing and able to commit to making food drops to elderly and vulnerable people in their communities. From disaster springs a bit of hope.The early narrative that said we shouldnt worry too much because coronavirus "only" seriously affects the elderly and those with underlying health conditions has been roundly criticised with its quiet assumption that the elderly and the vulnerable have less value than those with robust health and youth.We need to go a step further and really prioritise choices that will put prioritising the worst affected groups to the fore.As social distancing takes its toll wersquore going to need community to get us through.

title: scottish-council-tells-woman-must-apply-keep-pink-door---single-complaint
story: Council chiefs ordered the North Berwick homeowner to submit retrospective planning proposals for the colour refresh - designed to fit in with other homes in the area which have entrances painted red, yellow and blue.:Scottish council spends more than pound, on flights despite declaring climate emergencyBut the decision clearly irked one local, who complained the home - located in Dirleton Avenue - was in the picturesque seaside townrsquos conservation area.The complainant argued that, given the homersquos historic status, any move to change the frontage would have to be subject to council approval.However, the homeowner, who has not been named, pointed out the door is not visible from the street because of high hedges and its corner location.And she said she had been told by planning officers that they had only received one complaint about the colour of the door.Applying for planning permission for the paintwork, which is described as coral, she said: ldquoI had no idea that I needed planning permission for this and assumed it would be okay as there are many other strong coloured front doors in our local streets.ldquoOur door was chipped and neglected and I was aiming to make it appear smarter ndash it very much ties in with my design aesthetic and these colourful front doors are becoming increasingly popular in both conservation areas and outwith.As well as producing photographs of other properties with boldly painted doors, the applicant points out that one neighbouring house has pink rendering on its walls.:Whisky and cheese pairings among projects given Scottish Government food fundingShe added: ldquoWe invested considerable money in upgrading the front door and the gilded lettering and have received many compliments.The planning application is being considered by council officers.

story: Dr Lisa Cameron announced the move on social media in the early hours of this morning.She said she had been forced to cancel her constituency surgeries on medical advice.Dr Cameron, , had been in a debate with Tory mental health minister Nadine Dorries, who was diagnosed with the virus on Tuesday.Dr Cameron, the MP for East Kilbride, Strathaven and Lesmahagow since , later reported feeling fatigued and developed a dry cough and swollen glands.She wrote on Twitter: ldquoApologies for such short notice but after two NHS consultations tonight the out of hours doctor has confirmed I must self-isolate for one week.ldquoHope to be feeling better soon. title: msps-consider-proxy-voting-help-balance-family-life-holyrood
story: MSPs are being asked whether they would welcome proxy voting being introduced ndash after an SNP politician is quitting Holyrood because they have to spent too much time away from their family.Holyrood is launching a consultation with MSPs on whether new rules and procedures for proxy voting should be brought in.If pushed forward, under some circumstances, MSPs could have their votes on items submitted by other politicians on their behalf.The move comes after SNP MSP Gail Ross announced last month that she will quit the Scottish Parliament at next yearrsquo election.The Caithness, Sutherland and Ross MSP cited spending too much time away from her family as one reason behind her decision to step away from the Scottish Parliament next year.She said: ldquoI want to be able to spend more time with my family, to watch my son grow up and to be more involved in local issues, things I cannot presently do.ldquoThe sheer size of the area I represent also means that I am having dficulty in reaching every part of the constituency on a regular basis and I am not able to represent my constituents in the way they deserve and rightly expect.Ms Ross said she had previously asked whether it would be possible for MSPs to take part in meetings via video link or vote remotely.She added that ldquo we are to encourage into politics more young people with families who live far away from Edinburgh, this has to be considered.Her SNP colleague, Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell, has also announced she will be stepping back at the  elections in a bid to spend home time with her family.She said that while her job is "immensely rewarding", it is "demanding in terms of pressure and time".She added that she hopes to "spend a little more time with my boys at home".Changes to the rules have been welcomed by former Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson, who is also not standing at next years elections.She said: "If the Scottish Parliament is absolutely sure that it wants to be still considered the most family-friendly parliament in the world,it wants to hang on to MSPs,it wants to encourage more young women to come in, it has to start listening to MSPs that are making suggestions about how we can make this better, and itrsquos not just about women, itrsquos about whoever is the primary carer, that easily could well be and should well be in some cases the man, certainly in this day and age."In the UK Parliament, the House of Commons is currently piloting proxy voting for new parents and those who have recently adopted - with the procedures having been used by more than  MPs since they were first introduced in January .Meanwhile the National Assembly of Wales permits proxy voting for members who are absent because of childbirth, who have just become adoptive or surrogate parents, and those who have suffered either a miscarriage or stillbirth.The consultation will run until Thursday April .
